column4: hi..can anyone give me a command to recursively delete all NON HIDDEN files and folder
find . ! -name '.*'     # If that looks right, add -delete at the end
Oh and you might want -type f to only target files
find . -type f ! -name '.*'   make sure you try on a test tree/copy first
yea that works so next i just do this? find . -type f ! -name '.*' -delete ? or -exec rm -f {} \;
Yes. the -exec is the portable way, while -delete is specific to GNU find (which ubuntu has)
sorry, any idea why it refuses to delete folders? i have specified -rf with rm
The parent directories have probably been deleted first.
Oh, and your find only targets files
so i need to add -type df ?
If I understood what you wanted to do correctly, you risk removing hidden files if you do rm -rf
Maybe you rather want find . -depth -type d ! -name ".*" -exec echo rmdir {} \;
rmdir will only remove a directory if it is empty
thats a safer solution i guess. thanks again
Or in other words, you restore from backup.
